Reviews.text:
This Plantronics Audio 478 Stereo USB Headset came to me via the Amazon Vine Reviewers Program. It was a timely for me because I had just ordered a new computer and was planning on setting up Skype. I am an avid Facebook user and recently learned that I will be having shoulder surgery, so I will be using voice activated software to keep up with Facebook and other computer tasks - needing a solid headset with microphone to do so.

The Headset:
Solidly made, folds for storage with a small, but accurate microphone, this headset is comfortable to wear for long periods of time. It fits completely over your ears - but it's not noise cancelling - noise still gets through - which frankly I like if I'm working so I can hear others come and go in the room.

The cord is about 6' long from the USB port connection to the headset. The control for on/off for Skype hits at about waist level when the headset it on me (I'm 5'6" with an average length torso). The boom for the microphone comes out from one of the earpieces. Because it rotates like the hands on a clock - you can have it coming from the left or right - whatever is comfortable for you. The headset is big enough to fit on larger noggins, and some with smaller heads may actually find it lose fitting.

Music and Gaming VS. Skype:
To use this headset with Skype you have to first go to Plantronics' website and download specific drivers that work with Skype. It's quick and easy to do so, and once I logged into Skype the software had no problem recognizing the headset immediately. Voice transfer was clear with only a slight echo occasionally. The microphone is noise-cancelling (giving a clear reproduction of your voice without noise in the room coming through too). Overall I'd rate it a 5 out of 5 for internet calls or video chat, using Skype, iChat or Windows Live Messenger. It works with both PC's and MAC too.

As for music playback - I thought the sound to be lacking. I tried several genres of music, adjusted my PC's output to Bass Boost, etc..., but I really wasn't impressed with these headphones for true music enjoyment. I think it's adequate, but not much more in this area.

I also used this headset for playing the game L.A. Noire: The Complete Edition. I liked it, but hardcore gamers would find it lacking enough 'umph' I'm sure, and without the noise cancelling earphones, you have to turn up the volume quite a bit on your PC as sound is lost through the earpieces of the headset.

Conclusion:
These headphones are a good choice for those who frequently use Skype or similar chat software for work or pleasure. Also a good choice for software programs like: Dragon NaturallySpeaking Home, Version 11. However, they are not the best choice for music reproduction - lacking depth of sound and noise cancelling earphones - or for gaming, but do work for both. The headset is compatible via USB with both PC's and MAC. For my needs for Skype and voice recognition software, this headset will work great.

If you're more into music or gaming and want noise cancelling as a feature, consider these options: Plantronics GameCom 367 Closed-Ear Gaming Headset or Plantronics .Audio 655 USB Multimedia Headset which actually cost less and are geared towards those specific listening needs.

1/4/2012:
Used this headset for several hours while talking via Google Talk (free long distance calls through the end of the year 2012, but you need a Gmail account to do so...) on both local and long distance calls. All the calls were clear to both me as the user of the headset and to my call recipients. Actually the call recipients said that other than the number that came over caller ID, they noticed no difference in sound quality (me using this headset over the Internet) than if I was using a land line directly from my house. They said it was better than my cell phone for clarity (I have an LG Optimus with Virgin Mobile service).

1/16/2012:
Finding the headset to be uncomfortable on my ears after about 30 minutes. Call quality is still good, but not the most comfortable of wear.

10/19/13:
Still using this headset and enjoying the call/voice recording capabilities. I use it to do screencast recordings, and used it while working for a company's customer service department. Its durability has been excellent, but I must admit I do treat it gently; folding it up and putting it in its bag when not in use. The extra-long cord has been great, and I enjoy the way I can look down and see if the mute button is engaged (red light on) or not.
Reviews.title: Good for Skype, Google Talk  and Facebook integration, audiophiles will find it lacking

Reviews.text:
I worked in customer service for awhile, and most that I've known use plantronics headsets. There is a reason for this.

When you first open the package you see the headset all folded up. It comes with a cloth bag as well that wouldn't protect it much, but might keep some dust off of it.

What I like about this headset.
 - Very lightweight, it may seem a bit fragile, but being lightweight is great for feeling good on the head.
 - Sound quality reception/mic is very good.
 - Very adjustable, the ear pads swivel which allow for a very comfortable fit.

What I don't like
 - The volume up/down/mute switch seems to be up to high. Instead of being able to hold it in my hand on my lap, I end up always having to reach for it, or grab it and spin it around to see if I'm muted.
 - The pickup/hangup button doesn't seem to work, I am on OS X and haven't installed any software, so this may be why, don't really need it.
 - Cords on both ears instead of just one

Bottom line, this is the best usb headset I've used, most comfortable, sound/mic isn't an issue, and it works great every time. I just wish there were a few small changes.
Reviews.title: I love this headset (albeit one minor flaw)

Reviews.text:
this is really an amazing headset.

Likes
1. cheap ($30 inclusive of S) yet very high quality (*see below)
2. the voice quality, both receiving and outgoing is "pro" standard. i verified by calling my land line and left voice mail. also had friends called me from their cell phones and land line. the feedback was unanimously "pro like". or "pro". no echo, no background noises, comfortable to listen to.
3. easy to operate. pluck and use from USB port. no need to download any driver or software. (*you must download a driver from Platronics if you want the remote on/off call button to activate. i do not need this function thus no need to download any driver)
4. no conflict with other USB devices. i have a Logitech webcam device attached. both devices work seamlessly, no need for any adjustment on my part.
5. easy on the eyes. nice aesthetic.

Dislikes
1. carrying bag is cheesy. should consider providing a hard carrying case for traveler.
2. USB cable too short. a longer cable would offer a little more flexibility for users. bear in mind in today's PC world, laptop performs the function of a desk top. even better option is to introduce a wireless headset.

for $30-, this headset "Exceeds Expectation".
Reviews.title: Amazing Quality @ Amazing Price

Reviews.text:
These affordable corded headphones are OK, but not to fall in love with.

If you Skype from your laptop or desktop computer, and listen to music between calls, OK.

If you wear headphones a lot, you'll want better comfort and sound.

For "on-the-go," you could want something more compact.

USB connection -- not for phones.

PROs:

 - Affordable
 - Plug and play
 - Handy control stick - Mute, volume, and call answer/terminate
 - Noise canceling mic (earphones are not noise canceling)

OKs:

 - Music fidelity is OK, not great
 - Comfort is OK, not great. Not for wearing hours on end
 - Open-air foam earpieces allow you to hear your surroundings (good or bad)
 - Secure enough fit, just barely
 - Fold-able, but not super compact
 - 1 year warranty

- - - Alternatives - - -

I have not tried them, but I would consider:

- Sennheiser PC 36 USB Headset
- Logitech USB Headset H530
- Logitech Laptop Headset H555
- Creative Labs Sound Blaster Tactic 3D Alpha USB Gaming Headset
Reviews.title: Lots of OK

Reviews.text: I use this set on a Mac PowerPC 2.0Ghz system. The Plantronics Audio 478 worked perfectly out of the box after plugging it into a powered USB hub. It's an excellent buy for $29.97. When using with Skype, access the Preferences/Audio. Select Plantronics .Audio 478 USB for audio output and input. The headset is comfortable, has excellent sound quality, and works as intended. My first call was on Skype for 1Hr +. I barely noticed the headset during the call. I played with the inline functions - worked fine.
Reviews.title: Excellent Plug & Play Mac Headset.  A winner for the price!

Reviews.text:
The Plantronics .Audio 478 USB Stereo Headset is good quality for a compact headset. It easily folds to fit in the included 9" x 5" pouch.

The headset is very lightweight and is and comfortable to wear but stays in place without putting too much pressure on the ears.

Sound quality is excellent: voices seem natural with no crackling and no echo as with some headsets. The microphone is on the left earpiece but it swivels 270 degrees so the headset can be reversed to use the mouthpiece on the right side. The cord is rubbery and about 6 feet long. It has a USB plug.

The 478 works both with Windows and Mac. In addition to volume up, volume down, and mute functions as on the control set on the cord of most headsets, there is a call answer button that will work with Skype if software is downloaded from Plantronics.

Two suggestions for improvement: the metal finish on the plastic looks cheap and the foam earpiece cushions do not seem to be removable for washing or replacement. I tried to call Plantronics about the foam but their customer support hours are 8AM to 5PM PST Monday to Friday. I suggest getting some disposable foam covers to protect them unless you plan to discard this headset when they become soiled.
Reviews.title: Good quality headphones for making calls from your computer

Reviews.text:
I bought this headset to use for my work as a work-at-home customer service agent.

I don't like the big heavy headsets nor do I like the big heavily padded ear muffs as they make my ears sweat, e[...]

This set was the perfect solution and offers very comfortable and lightweight quality. The volume and mute control is placed at the perfect location on the wire as well. This set allows my ears to breathe as well unlike so many other headsets out there.

The plug-n-play convenience of the USB connection top it off and make this headset a quality, long lasting device that I am VERY happy with!

Easy 5 out of 5 score!
Reviews.title: Heavy, every day use for six months, still working wonderfully!  Very comfortable and lightweight!  Awesome sound & mic quality!

Reviews.text:
QUICK SUMMARY: This headset works well with my laptop computer. While using Skype, the sound I heard was very clear, like the person was sitting next to me. The other person reporting excellent sound, too -- much, much better than when I used my laptop's built-in microphone. The fact that this set is foldable and more easily transported makes this a great headset to own. Highly recommended!

WHAT I LIKE:

- Comfortable fit. I didn't feel pressure on my head or ears after wearing them for a while.
- The sound I heard was excellent for voice (I don't use headsets for music)
- The sound captured by the microphone was excellent (as reported to the one who heard me speak)
- Foldable design makes them easy to stow or transport
- The microphone boom kept away from my mouth (other headsets I've owned tend to bump into my mouth)
- Plug-n-play performance. Windows 7 recognized it right away for me. No drivers to install.

Usually I can make a comment or two about what could be done to improve a product I review, even if there was nothing I particularly disliked about that product. With this headset, nothing really comes to mind about what could be done to improve it. A headset should be comfortable to wear, provide good sound through the earpieces, capture and deliver sound well through the boom microphone. This headset does all of that. As long as there isn't an issue with reliability, I have no qualms about recommending this Plantronics headset.
Reviews.title: Wonderfully compact, great sound and performance

Reviews.text: Very good audio quality, but poor build quality. Mike portion broke almost immediately. Not apparently repairable. Not clear how/whether this can be returned.
Reviews.title: Plantronics headset

Reviews.text: This headset has a great sound quality when used for calling (listening and speaking). But, as it is not supported on Linux (I mean, you can plug it and use it normally, but you can't use the buttons to control the volume and mic), I had to write my own application.
Reviews.title: Greate sound quality, but I use Linux and had to write my own program to make it work.

Reviews.text: This is a great headset, I'm using it for training for a vitual agent and its great noise canceling is about 70% I would say but great quality. Mute and volume buttons are close by. I would recommend this product.
Reviews.title: Great buy

Reviews.text:
This headset has the best noise canceling mic that I've used. We are long time work from home people that give it about 7-10 hours of continuous use, daily. The cleaner has been vacuuming on the other side of a swinging french door to our office - with a vacuum that sounds like a high pitched jet engine, and the caller didn't even hear it. It does pretty well with background voices, but if there is someone sitting at the table with us talking loudly, it will pick up that sound. You can play a low to medium level music and have it not be heard.

I have 2 of these. They work better (noise canceling) than any cordless ones I've tried including Logitech H600, and some Skype ones from InStore shop.
Reviews.title: Best Noise canceling mic

Reviews.text: I bought these headphones for making tutorial videos for my computer science students. I had no trouble with them on my Windows 7 computer, but they seemed to be "dead" when I first tried them on a Mac. However, a quick call to tech support informed me that some Macs need adjustments in the System Preferences to change the input and output settings to use the headphones. I'm a satisfied customer.
Reviews.title: Suitable for both PC and Mac

Reviews.text:
I use this for recording videos to upload to the web.

Pros:
Like the fold up design as that makes the headset a bit easier to take on the road; does not fold up to a compact size, just so you don't break it in transport.

Light enough.

Pretty comfortable. I would not want to wear it for hours.

Cons:
Microphone is a bit too sensitive and needs a foam wind cover included. I use it in my office and when the A/C is on it literally picks up the breeze coming out of the register as if I was outside.

Mute/volume buttons are large (not that big of a deal) and heavy (big deal) without any clip to hold them steady. Thus if you move your head rapidly while recording they can bang into objects and the microphone picks that up.

Rattle in the right earphone when it came.
Reviews.title: Not bad but some issues in design

Reviews.text:
I just purchased this headset. I use Windows 7, and Dragon NaturallySpeaking premium edition. Unfortunately Windows did not recognize this headset. I was able to get it to be recognized eventually, but Dragon does not recognize this now. It does fine with the Logitech. I may try one other fix, otherwise I will just sent these back. Just wanted to let others know who might be using Windows 7 and Dragon that this may not be something that will be usable.

I wanted to update this. I'm not sure what happened but I re-plugged the headset in, and it went ahead and uploaded the Windows updates, and indicated that it was current. I then went into Dragon, and change the microphone setting, and went ahead and tuned the mic, and it works perfectly. It is very accurate compared to the Logitech headset I used before. It is slightly less comfortable, but easily worn for several hours. I'm not sure what happened the first time around, but I wanted to make sure to update my review to indicate that these do work with Windows 7 and Dragon 12.5, and they are highly accurate.
Reviews.title: Does not work with Windows 7 and Dragon--UPDATED

Reviews.text:
This review has been edited to let people know this product crapped out before I'd even owned it for six months. It was working perfectly before, but now when I plug it in, the computer doesn't even recognize that a device is plugged in. It's like it's just dead. I tried all USB ports on four different computers to verify that the problem was the device and not a driver or computer issue.

I will update this to let you guys know if Plantronics honors their warranty.

Pros:

Skype-compatible inline controls
Good sound quality

Cons:

Slightly uncomfortable

After three months, I was pleased with it. I used it for Skype and for online gaming, and the sound quality and microphone were both better than I expected; the noise cancellation worked really well to cancel out background noise. The inline controls for Skype worked perfectly, and the software was so easy to download and install that even my elderly mother could do it when she used the same headset!

The only problem I had initially was some discomfort from the pressure of the ear pads on my ears. I have really sensitive ears, and the pressure on my ears began to hurt a bit after talking on Skype for a long time. That being said, most people are not that sensitive, and I was talking for hours. It's worth considering if that's a problem for you, but it's not fair to take a star off for something that's not a defect or oversight. It's still much more comfortable than any other headset I've found.
Reviews.title: Crapped out after less than 6 months

Reviews.text: This headset is not designed to be worn by humans! Very, Very uncomfortable. The overall design is ridiculous. The headband is not adjustable and is flat across the top and is way too tight. The ear pads do not swivel enough be able to self adjust to the pinching of the headband. There is no clip for the very heavy volume controller, so the weight of the controller constantly pulls down on headset. Very bad design. I can wear these for about 30 seconds before they begin to hurt my ears. Highly disappointing.
Reviews.title: Plantronics plainly painful headset

Reviews.text: My wife and I have a consulting business we operate out of our home office and do quite a bit of training for clients via webinars. We've gone through several headsets in the past six or seven years. This one is by far the best we've used. Computer (we use Mac Minis) recognized the headset instantly. It's comfortable to wear even after 60 or 90 minutes. Sound quality -- both sending and receiving -- is amazing given the price.
Reviews.title: Best headset we've ever used for doing webinars

Reviews.text: I use this with Dragon Naturally Speaking and it works flawlessly. For the price I think this might be the best on the market and USB microphones are absolutely the way to go.
Reviews.title: Works wonderfully with Dragon Naturally Speaking

Reviews.text: Bought this headset and it works fine. I really like the integrated controls for skype. Unfortunately as of Dec 2013 Skype will no longer suppor these controls. I do hope a fix becomes available otherwise I feel a bit let down by Plantronics.
Reviews.title: Skype support ends per December 2013

Reviews.text: I bought this unit to replace a damaged headset for my Rosetta Stone application. This was a perfect replacement with controls to mute, etc. It works really well and I highly recommend it.
Reviews.title: Perfect for my use (Rosetta Stone)

Reviews.text:
It's so great I bought two. Planning to buy another for the hell of it.
I have several headsets and microphones. From a Gamecom 780 to standalone desktop table microphones along with Audio Technica headphones. But nothing beats the voice clarity, and the comfort of this headset. It literally IS noise-canceling. I had my family playing karaoke and movies in the background and the background sound of that was lowered to my friend, whom I was playing games with online, making my voice clear and hearable.

The sound is enough for casual music listening. I'm no audiophile but owning several audio technicas and jvcs and kosses, this seems to be pretty damn good. As for how it feels like on your head? If you've ever owned koss portapros, just imagine that, but more lighter and not-so tight hugging.

Overall the best con for me is the mic and price on this thing. it's like plantronic's best product right now.

PROS:
- Mic sounds amazing *
- Lightweight, comfortable as hell
- Plug and play, none of that bs driver unless you want to be able to end/answer calls with the button on the headset cord
- Sounds great
- Skype certified ( I believe this is when Plantronics hires skype to do testing on their product, and if it works well and is clear, it gets a skype certification )
- It's so great that according to reviews some electronic stores are using this among employees to communicate

CONS:
- Seems very flimsy. I have been using it for a year though, and dropped it about 4x a week. Nothing has broke it. So it's pretty durable.
- This is not related to this product, but this goes for 50 dollars at local stores for some reason, while its 25 online. Weird.
- That's it. This is great.

Hell i'm going to pick up another one later for back-ups.
Reviews.title: This is literally the best headset for the price on Amazon right now.

Reviews.text:
I just started using Google Voice and looked for a decent heaadphone mic.

I purchased the Sennheiser PC-151- thought the quality would be great -WRONG!!

I went to my local Fry's store and asked for suggestions.

They said the Plantronics 478 is what they use ( and also said a USB connection is better than the plug in mic that I had.

I tried them and WOW.

Crystal clear.

I would have purchased these from Amazon, but Fry's ( which was charging $50.00) matched the price-$24.59

Sorry. Amazon - next order is for you.

If you need a headphone mic, get these, you won't be sorry.
Reviews.title: Headphone mic

Reviews.text:
I chose these headphone because I needed a good set of headphones for my games like Battlefield 3 and Skyrim. If you were previously using standard usb external speakers, these headphones will greatly improve your gaming experience. You can literally hear the enemies footsteps and the direction they're coming from! The sound quality is 10/10.

 Another thing I love about these headphones are how comfortable they are. Once I put them on, I almost forgot that I'm wearing them. They don't dig into your head like bigger, bulkier headphones that I've used in the past. The microphone on this also works very well 10/10. The only thing I don't like about this headphone is the fact that the cords length is kind of long for me. The cord sometimes gets caught under the wheels of my chair. But then again, I would rather have the cord too long rather than too short. Overall, I would recommend this to anyone that's looking for new headphones.
Reviews.title: FANTASTIC GAMING HEADPHONES!

Reviews.text:
For 50 dollars, you could do a heck of a lot worse when it comes to a computer headset. With an easy setup, decent audio quality, and sleek design, it's a no-brainer when it comes to recommending the Plantronics Audio 478 Headset.

Comfort is always a top priority when it comes to a headset, and this pair is fine in the category. They're very lightweight and after wearing these for well over an hour I felt no discomfort. They fold nicely when not in use, so when you need to put these away they won't take up a ton of space around your computer. These aren't noise canceling, but you'll notice that the earphones are pretty small (unlike ear cups), but I didn't find this to be distracting. The cord is 6 feet long, so you won't have any problem reaching for the volume if you need to push away from your desk.

The sound quality is decent, but not great. However, for a 50 dollar pair of headphones you can't expect much more. I used this with Skype (which is one of the things this headset is promoting the most) and voice clarity was crystal clear. When I turned up the volume there was noticeable feedback, but unless you're deaf this won't be an issue. I also used it with iChat on my Mac Mini, and the voice clarity was very good. Overall, I'd recommend this headset with flying colors if you only intend to use these for online chatting.

I used these as a standard pair of headphones for music and video games, and while they are acceptable in this capacity, they're definitely not going to impress you. There is no bass or equalizer to utilize, and there is always noticeable distortion when the volume is turned up high. Again, these aren't really made for gaming or music use, but they will get you by until you buy headphones specifically made for that type of thing.

For what this headset claims to accomplish, they are a success.
Reviews.title: Solid headset

Reviews.text: I use headsets a LOT during the day, so I need one that's at least moderately comfortable over extended periods of time. This is the third model of Plantronics headset I've tried in as many years - while the first two were of flimsier build, they were much easier on the ears (my head, by the way, is normal size!). This one has a tighter fit that starts hurting the ears pretty quick and can bring on a tension headache after prolonged use. Time hasn't 'broken it in' either...
Reviews.title: Uncomfortable

Reviews.text: Purchased this teleconferencing when working from home. The sound is perfect for that situation, the price is right and the set is comfortable --- I have no complaints! It's worth the price for my purposes.
Reviews.title: Use it for teleconferencing when I'm working from home

Reviews.text: I have about 5 headsets including wireless. I have a conference call at least once per day. If its in the morning, the wireless isn't charged enough. If the conference is over an hour, the wireless loses its juice. I got this USB to resolve the aforementioned issues and it works as intended. Sound quality is great, comfortable wear, plug and play.
Reviews.title: I work from home

Reviews.text:
I purchased this headset specifically, because I am now taking a weekly online class that is 4 hours long and requires a headset with a mic to reduce feedback when doing group work. The problem is that I easily get headaches from headbands or other bulky headsets. Something about the pressure is way too much. I also easily get tension headaches, so I definitely have a muscle thing going on. I have to be just as picky when buying sunglasses ... :P This headset had good reviews, had a USB plug, downloads drivers automatically and looked like it might more comfortable because it is listed as wide, adjustable and less bulky. Yay! I was right on that account. This one is more comfortable and I am less likely to get a headache. I have another Plantronic headset that may be nicer by others' account (lots of padding, better coverage over the ears etc.), but I just cannot wear it for any amount of time whatsoever as the things that make other people love it create too much pressure for me.

In addition, the ease of use and built in controls are a bonus. It is truly plug and play. The only reason I am not giving it all 5 stars is that I am now all of a sudden, after weeks of not issues, having trouble with it on one of my computers. The headphones don't work, but the mic does. The sound will come out of my speakers. However, I can plug and play it on my laptop and it works just fine. So I am pretty sure it has something to do with a recent update and I just haven't figured it out yet (It could be a MS update but more likely a recent Adobe classroom software update that just happened as I am using this in that environment for my online class). I doubt it is actually the headphones themselves as they work perfectly fine on the other computer. I just figured I should mention it in full disclosure.

If you are easily prone to headaches from other headsets or sunglasses then I suggest giving these a try!
Reviews.title: Great for someone who easily gets headaches from other headphones

Reviews.text: Clear voice, plug and play. I like the idea of foldable headphones. Build quality is durable. Does not work with IMac.
Reviews.title: Very good foldable headphones

Reviews.text: Very nice and portable, too! If you wear glasses or reading glasses, anything over the ear or behind the neck just doesn't work. This one is easy on the head (no headaches from the band being too tight) and provides clear sound, speaking and listening.
Reviews.title: Great product and good price!

Reviews.text: Pleased with the audio quality and recorded sound for the money. I've used this for a few audio voice control apps, as well as recording a voice over in a pinch when I couldn't get to the studio. No one had any issues with the quality of the recording, once we punched the bass a little.
Reviews.title: Good quality for the money.

Reviews.text: Love these headphones. They sound great, they integrate easily with my PC. I use them for gaming and can either wear the full headphone or hang them around my neck and just talk thru the mic. The only thing I didn't like, which is supposed to be a feature and most would probably like it, is that the headphones bend in two places to make them easy to store and pack. It's a cool design, but when they bend on my neck they pull the hair. I also wish they made these in bluetooth because i get sick of the cord always being in my way.
Reviews.title: Great headphones!

Reviews.text: not even a year and it's stop working already. Too bad they don't even have a warranty plan. Now I have to buy another set.
Reviews.title: this will not last longer than 1 year.

Reviews.text:
I've enjoyed this headset so much, I've ordered another, just in case. I use it for Dictate Dragon NaturallySpeaking on my Mac. It's perfect. It's not heavy and does not get in the way. It's also comfortable. Personally, I recommend it if you do any speech to text or have a need for a microphone that will always be the same distance from your mouth every time you use it.

As a student, I write a gratuitous amount of papers. Utilizing speech to text software speeds up my productivity in completing my papers. This microphone is perfect!
Reviews.title: Excellent product! Great for speech to text..

Reviews.text:
QUICK REVIEW:
Pros: Comfortable, great sound quality (listening to music, has a surprising amount of bass feedback), automatically syncs up with Skype (no software to download/install, no settings to change).
Cons: Looks a bit silly, fits my large head very well, might be a looser fit on small heads, controls hanging from the headset are at a weird length, right around the lower chest.
Overall: Love it; quality to price ratio is excellent.
Reviews.title: QUICK REVIEW: Love it; quality to price ratio is excellent.

Reviews.text:
I like the $18 Microsoft LC-3000 better for voice/Skype because they are more comfortable, and costing less is a bonus. Here is my full review:

I bought the following headsets and compared them. I didn't intend to buy so many, but was just disappointed with the performance of my earlier purchases and I was not satisfied until I got these. Here is what I think of the ones that I tried:

Sound reference: On scale of 1 to 10:

Worst free airline headphones I have heard being a 1.
$6 Panasonic RPHJE120K being a 6.
Sennheiser HD580 Jubilee being a 10 (even though there are better headphones out there, like the Sennheiser electrostatics).
Upgraded version of these: Sennheiser HD 580 Professional Headphone

Razer Kraken PRO:

I really expected these to be good because they got good reviews. They look nice and high quality. They are very comfortable. The sound is dreadful. Sound quality on that scale - 3. Not usable for music. Very muddy and sloppy bass that drawfs the mids and highs. Vastly worse sounding than the $6 Panasonic ear buds. You may find them a bit much in size if you just want to do Skype or voice dictation and will never listen to music or play games.

Turtle Beach Z11:

As comfortable as the Razer. Decent looking but not quiet as nice looking as the Razer, but costs less than half the price and the sound quality is light-years better. Not even in the same universe. Sound quality - 8. Excellent for listing to music for enjoyment.

Bonus points - has a 4-pole plug so you can plug it into an iPhone or I assume probably a Macbook and the mic works. Good enough to listen to music on for enjoyment.If I had these on for music and the Sennheisers were 20 feet away, I would not be motivated to get up grab the Sennheisers as they are close enough that I have to A/B them to remember the differences.

Plantonics 478:

Not comfortable - too much pressure into ears (I don't even have a large head).
Good if you want portable as they fold.
Sound - 4. Not good enough for music for pleasure.
I would say they would be good for voice-only use, except they were not comfortable enough, so I cannot even recommend them really at all.

Microsoft LX-3000:

Much more comfortable than the Plantonics.
Sound - 3. Not good enough for music.

Reviews.text:
First of all - for Skype or any other audio calling software this is EXCELLENT. The noise reduction is amazing!

Reviews.text:
The sound quality on these headphones is better than expected. While I did not get these for listening to music, I would have no problem using them for that, if only they were more comfortable for extended wear (more than an hour). For my Mac (10.8.5 Mountain Lion) these headphones were indeed plug-and-play with all the buttons on the headphone cord (mic mute, output volume up/down) working as expected. As reported by others, only the telephone pick-up/hang-up button does not function on the Mac for lack of software.

Some folks apparently have had trouble using these on their Mac. Try this test on your Mac right now -- find the little speaker icon in the menu bar at the top of the screen. Normally when you click on this you get a volume control slider. But if you hold down the 'option' key and then click on the speaker icon, you should get a drop-down menu that allows you to pick your input and output devices. (If you are using a non-Apple keyboard on your Mac, try the ALT or 'windows' key instead.) If you see that menu, then when you plug these headphones in, you should see two new choices in this menu, both labeled Plantronics .Audio 478. One is for input (the mic) and one for output (the headphones). If you do not get a drop down menu, this is probably because you have an old version of Mac OS X, so you'll need to use the system preferences instead. But the idea is the same, when plugged into the USB port, Plantronics should become a recognized device.
Reviews.title: Tip for Mac Users

Reviews.text:
This is how easy it is to use the Plantronics .Audio 478 ... wait for it ... you plug it in.

It was a little tricky taking it out of its box because there are a few twists and turns (be careful), but in the end, it's a snap. I plugged it in to two different computers, my Vista desktop and my Windows 7 laptop. Both of them immediately recognized the headset and was talking and listening in minutes.

It is billed as being the best at working with Skype. Well, they aren't kidding. In yet another plug-and-play process, Skype registered the type of headset I was using and the buttons for picking up a Skype call when it came in worked like a charm. But none of this is worth much. I've not had too many problems getting USB headsets to work. The real clincher here is with the sound quality for the speakers and microphone: it is truly superb, of the first water!

The bass is rich and resonant while the higher tones are sparkling. The microphone is incredibly sensitive but not overly so. My callers say my voice comes through clear as a bell. I've also used the headset controlling on VATSIM, which is a virtual air traffic control environment. It worked steadily and without fail for over four hours. Truly an excellent headset.

The only possible problem is with the folding/collapsibility of the headset. You have got to be very careful folding it away and opening it. Once it is open, it fits snugly without cramping anywhere, on the top of the head or on the ears themselves. The microphone swivels in and out of the way very well. Good design, but it just looks fragile. Not saying it is, but it looks that way folded up.

The carrying sac is a nice touch.

5 stars with some reservations for its possible fragility.
Reviews.title: The Sound is Superb

Reviews.text:
First of all let me state the caveat that I'm not an audiophile and I don't know how this $50 headset compares to expensive high-end headphones for sound quality but I actually used them to listen to music and thought the quality was very good; better than an expensive pair of Shure earphones I have. Listening to music is not the targeted use for this headset. It appears to be targeted to VOIP applications like Skype. For that it works well and I thought the sound quality was also very good. The inline controls work perfect. The plug and play installation is a snap. I wore them for many hours and they are very comfortable. After a short-period of time you can hardly tell you have them on. The 6-foot USB cable is adequate.

Overall I have no problem recommending this headset and at $50 it is a very good value.

Reviews.text:
I bought this headset based on its Amazon reviews and price. I finally decided on this device against the Logitech Wireless H600/H800 line of headsets due to my previous experience with wireless headsets. I needed the headset for VOIP calls at my office; this headset and the Telephone app on the mac replaced my bulky SIP phone. Since wireless devices I used prior to purchasing this headset tended to produce so much latency that it made conversations unbearable, I opted for a cheap USB set.

The build quality is cheap and feels like it could easily break. The design of the headset is unassuming and simple. The cable that extends from both sides of the headset are cumbersome and could be relegated to a single side, but I'm assuming this somehow has lowered the cost of manufacturing. It elegantly folds away, which was also a consideration. On my head, it feels comfortable enough to make calls and have conversations without too much discomfort. It doesn't feel good, but it doesn't feel bad enough that I regret getting the headset. I don't get a chance to use the buttons as they do not work with the Telephone app that I use, but I have pushed them to see anyway. Again, the buttons also feel very cheap and loose.

All in all, this is a very affordable headset and worth the low price for casual phone conversations on VOIP or Skype. It's not the best design and not meant for ultimate comfort, but it does it's job with little to no latency on calls. Since purchasing I haven't had echoes or delayed voice during conversations.

Notable features include:

 Headset folds down and can be easily tucked away
 USB connected
 Quick buttons for use with some applications

Lets weigh the pros and cons of this device.

Pros:

 Good as an entry-level and casual-use headset
 Low latency USB connection
 Affordable price
 Decent fit and not too uncomfortable
 Tucks away with the foldable design

Cons

 Cheap plastic feel and boring design
 Wires extending from both sides is cumbersome
 Not ideal for comfort and extended use
 Tied down to range of wired cable

For $25 (at time of writing) and the very light use it gets at work, I think this is an excellent headset for casual VOIP usage. I wouldn't use these for gaming or long phone conversations.

Reviews.text: I do lots of online meetings with Skype and GoToMeeting both at home and at coffeeshops. My big headset did not work for me... did not fit in my "man bag." My earbuds with inline mic fit the bag but sound quality was terrible in a noisy Starbucks. The Plantronics Audio 478 Stereo USB Headset (Audio 478) really solves the problem. The price is right at USD 25.00. They fold into a neat little package that rides well in my Timbuk2 bag. People have complimented me on the sound quality. And background noise is mostly cancelled. Recommended.

Reviews.text:
I purchased this headset because my microphone port stopped working on my computer - the USB helps with that, obviously. The headphones provide clear audio (for speaking - I haven't tried them with music or anything like that) and others on calls with me have told me that they can hear me very clearly. (I did ask them if they could hear me okay - it wasn't a spur-of-the-moment exclamation!)

Reviews.text: Works great for me on both Sametime and Skype. Sound quality is good and I it folds down well for easy transport.

Reviews.text: Good product, I use it for Rosetta Stone. It works really good, sounds really good and had a nice length to the cord. The foldable option to them is great too!

Reviews.text:
I bought this headset to replace a Logitech headset that started to fall apart after a year. I've had the Plantronics headset for about six months. It's a very nice headset if you accept its limitations. I work from home as a programmer.

I use the headset for listening to music and for Skype teleconferences. For listening to music, it's pretty good, but not spectacular. Good enough when listening to music is your secondary focus. It provides very little isolation from external noises in the room, so it's probably not so good in a noisy environment.

Teleconferencing performance is very good. I come through very clearly with no noise (in a quiet room). The voice quality is better than my landline. The fit and comfort is good enough to wear it for a few hours at a stretch. I have a large head and the headset can be adjusted for a good fit.

Like all headsets I have seen, it looks very fragile. I'd buy a hard case if I planned to do much travelling with it. Mine stays at home, hanging on my monitor when I'm not using it.

Reviews.text: Just pluggin and answer a couple questions and you are able to use this product on your pc computer, I am running windows 8 on this system so do not know how it works on other systems. Unplug it and I am back to regular speakers, provides clear sound when talking to others people via skype which I use on all of my calling whether it be business or personal.

Reviews.text: i bought this to use on my weekly multiple skype conference group calls. it was exactly what i was looking for. the headset fits nicely but goes get a little warm around the ears after awhile. it works seamlessly with the skype application. however on the Mac, i can't answer the calls directly from the headset nor can i initiate a call/hangup either. everything has to be done via the skype application. however i do use the volume controls directly on the headset control. for the price, everything was really clear and audible.

I downloaded some software from the Plantronics site, which comes with the same problem: no clear instruction on how to use it. As a result my use is limited to the mute button because I cannot make or receive calls on Skype without more explanation/instructions. Although the functionality must exist I do find this limitation a little annoying. I'm also left wondering whether it would work to automatically answer and make calls on RingCentral or Google voice.

We can hear her great. Wasn't expecting such great clarity from them. She loves them, lightweight and comfortable.

Reviews.text:
This is my second Plantronics USB headset. The first, a 470, still works, but the USB dongle it came with seems to now have problems with the mic input portion. I tested that headset with the dongle and it worked fine. I could get one of those Syba USB audio interfaces to replace it, but this gave me an excuse to have a second on hand.

Back to the 478. Like the 470, everyone I talk to says the incoming audio quality on their side is fantastic. Little to no background noise and most describe it as sounding like I'm in an audio booth. The sound quality through the earphones portion is surprisingly good with music. I wasn't buying it for that purpose, but it means I don't have to switch headphones at the office when transitioning between calls and listening to tunes. Not a ton of low end, but much better quality than I was hoping for.

I use this with Macs without a problem. Nothing to install though there is a Systems Preference widget you can get from their website. The volume and mute controls work, but alas, the answer button is only supported on PC's. That seems odd to me that that functionality isn't carried over. Hopefully with the recent announcement by Logitech that they will be supporting all their gaming devices fully on OS X, Plantronics will find a way to do the same.

For conferencing and light music listening, this headset is really hard to beat, especially at its price point. It doesn't have a super robust build, but my 470 (minus the dongle) has survived just fine for a couple of years so I expect this will as well. The fold flat feature is nice for transport and should help.
Reviews.title: Love Plantronics' USB headsets

Reviews.text: This headset has good sound quality, microphone is good as well (I've been asking different people I skype'd). It's perfect for Skype, but I also use them to listen to music, and I think the sound is fine. Worth its money.

Reviews.text:
Does not work on Windows Vista! The item has really good sound quality when I used it with my Windows 7 laptop, but when I tried to use it on my Vista desktop, I continually got the blue screen of death causing my computer to reboot itself. I tried it on another port and did not get the blue screen, but it was not being recognized by Skype or Windows. After looking for and loading drivers, deleting drivers and Skype, reloading Skype, reading Plantronics website, I finally called Plantronics support who told me this headset is not supported by Vista (not anywhere on their site at the time of writing)
Initially I was told to just buy another one that would work, however they finally agreed to do a replacement with another model that would work. I have used many Plantronics items over the last 10 years as I work from home, including CT10 and 12, cordless and wired headsets, and this is the first time I have had an issue, and they resolved it. Also, it works very well with Windows 7.

Reviews.text: I use this headset on my computer every day for programs like Skype and Ventrilo. I have also used it for voice recognition under Windows 7 with very good results.

Reviews.text:
I find this headset great for a few internet calls a day. I use it for hourly consulting calls and was looking to save money on calls. I also use it for personal calls while traveling internationally. I like the quality of the sound and comfort level and setup wasn't too difficult.

It was helpful for me when another reviewer mentioned how to use it, and what it works with, so I'll add to that. I use it with google talk and skype. To set it up you should go to plantronics.com/audio to install the driver for mac or pc for "audio 478" if you search on their website. For my mac I used the download on the left of the screen called "plantronics spokes software". You then have to activate your internet chat service to recognize the headset. You can login to skype and go to preferences > audio and/or your google account > settings > chat and tell it to recognize the microphone and speakers on the headset. It should be in a dropdown likely with your default computer settings/hardware.

Overall I'm very satisfied with this purchase and it's cheaper on amazon that through plantronics so that isn't bad either.

Reviews.text: This product folds as compact as possible for a USB/over the head device. I really like the length and flexiblity of the mic/boon. The body gear works for me, small frame women. It may be too tight for male or larger size head diameters. I do not care for in-the-ear devices and always use over the head. This product produces high quality recordings for audio engineers. I go through headsets like most people go through socks. This device is better than most other products in this price range.
Reviews.title: Plantronics 478 headset perfect for business travel

Reviews.text:
* I bought these to use with my work computer's "softphone" (Cisco IP Communicator) which lets me use my work phone while working at home; pretty slick tech!
* I have a big noggin, and these feel comfortable; the nice big ear pads rest comfortably against my ears and stay in place.
* I am now a big fan of binaural headsets (speakers on both ears) as it really enhances sound quality (the person on the other end is speaking inside your head, not off to the side).
* callers reported that the quality of my voice was excellent.
* I did not download any software for it, but Windows 7 recognized it and it was ready to go within seconds.
* as a USB device that shows up as a separate sound device, you can do a cool thing in at last *my* phone software: I can set it to be the headset for phone calls, but still have the phone ring through the computer speakers: as a result, I don't have to wear the headset all the time, just when I am taking or making a call. With a regular plug headset, it's like earphones: once you plug them in, the speakers stop working.
* The only negative I found is that the microphone picked up the wind noise from a fan I was using (that was blowing right at me from several feet away); I wish they had included a foam windscreen.
* Someone else had mentioned that the foam pads were not removable/replaceable and had suggested getting a set of covers, which I did: and when trying to stretch the new covers over them, I discovered they *are* removable :-), they are just installed so nicely that they don't look like it. So now I'm saving the other set Plantronics Ear Cushions (1-Pair) for if and when these go bad.
Reviews.title: comfortable, good sound quality

Reviews.text: Use this while playing games. I hate talking on online games so the mute button is nice. Crystal clear sound, works seemlessly with my Skype. Price makes it a good deal.
Reviews.title: Haven't found a complant

Reviews.text:
I love the Plantronics .Audio 478 Stereo USB Headset. Plain and simple. Here's why:

1. Very comfortable, soft, over-the-ear headphone, just snug enough to stay in place, just loose enough to allow for some airflow and plenty of comfort.

2. Excellent mic for the money! I've used these on Skype and I was told I sounded great. I did the Skype audio test run and heard my own test-recorded voice played back to me and it did really sound good. The midrange was great, the low range was great, and either I didn't have too many highs in my voice or they were filtered out to make the voice sound clean and pure. Great job, Plantronics!

3. Totally plug and play on my MacBook. All I had to do was go into System Preferences, go to the input and output controls, and select the Plantronics unit for each and I was ready to go! Full compatibility and functionality on the first shot, no drivers to download.

4. Easy inline controls, far enough down the cord to reach and see and adjust easily. Controls: Volume up, volume down, mute, and a call button (ask/answer call).

5. The whole unit folds down neatly into about the size of a pair of eyeglasses, and a travel pouch is provided to keep the headset safe inside your backpack or computer bag.

Highly recommended.
Reviews.title: Great sound coming and going

Reviews.text:
We routinely use VOIP for phone service so these were perfect for our needs. This is a nice headset - nothing fancy but gets the job done right. Inteded for use as a USB stereo headset with voip capacity including skype, this no nonsense set sound good and are simple to use. The inline controls are very intuitive as well as comfortable - volume and mute are easy to use. The folding might be nice but isn't really something that makes or breaks the set...just be aware, they don't fold that much. The overall footprint is still rather large. They will fold enough to tuck away nicely on the desk but don't expect a lot of space savings. Sound quality is good and distractions are kept to a minimum.

Negatives:
Size...these seem large over the head area even after some adjustment they had a tendency to drift a bit now and then. Nothing substantial but enough to be noticed. My spouse did not experience this issue whatsoever so it may depend upon hairstyle and head shape.
Can't plug into phone...the other disappointment was the inability to plug into a standard phone. Many VOIP providers allow traditional phone sets to extend the use of the phone rather than having to sit in front of the computer and we were hoping these would allow plugging into a phone. Unfortunately, that is not possible due to the exclusive use of the USB. Since these are designed as/for USB/computer use no points were docked but really wish there had been dual options...these would have been nearly perfect with both plugin types.
Reviews.title: Work very well for intended purpose.

Reviews.text:
Here are the issues:

1) The mute button has a tiny dim light backlighting an ornate little microphone silhouette with a slash through it (indicating mute) that is not easily visible when viewed at an angle. Compounding the problem is the fact that it is located along with the other buttons at chest level, which is the logical location for it, however the poor visibility of the light impels one to hold it up to see it. It is so close to the head that when I look at it I am nearly cross eyed and it takes a moment to focus. I find myself pulling the wire taut and thereby pulling on the headset to see the dim little light. Perhaps a younger person would not have these issues. Note to designer: After the speakers and the microphone, the mute button is the most important feature on the headset. It is used very often. It is imperative that the user can determine quickly with no doubt when it is engaged. It should be a large bright indicator light viewable from all angles and from a distance. When someone puts the headset on mute there is a REASON. They must have certainty under all conditions. When I look down to see if I am on mute (I can't hear that I am on mute) I want a fast unambiguous answer at any angle. I don't want to have to position the light. Sometimes I leave my desk temporarily while a conference call continues and then I look back to make certain my headset is on mute. This is going to be very difficult with this design. Perhaps you could have a little dim light to indicate the headset is plugged in (possibly a different color). Function should always dictate design. Beauty is functional, not an ornate first impression.

2) The headset has an individual wire running to each ear piece. I prefer a single wire running to one side, though I'll concede the button controls are more intuitive to grasp when they are located at the nexus of the dual wires centered on the torso. The dual wire system uses two thin wires rather than one thicker wire. Sometimes I step on the wire or catch it in some way (as with any headset) before I get up from my desk and the headset is subsequently torn from my head. The thin wires on this headset look a bit too delicate to sustain much roughness. Usually, headsets fail because a connection goes bad. This headset looks like it has a couple of weak links. Also, I don't like the lasso formed by the two wires as they come together. It is much more likely to catch things on my desk as I hang the headset up or grab them to put them back on.

Other than what I have written above, the headset seems well made. They do fold up very nicely and are as compact as practicable, however all things considered they are not that much more compact than the ones that don't fold up. As to how they sound, I'll leave that to others to comment on. My old headset sounds fantastic so I expect just as much from this one, that is a given. There is far too much attention paid and time spent discussing incremental improvements in sound that few people will notice or care about. The ergonomic design is the issue.

Paradoxically, my old Plantronics headset is, as a practical matter, better than this new one. Unfortunately, it was discontinued several years ago and I cannot buy it anymore. I am not nostalgic or sentimental, just stating the facts. Fortunately, years ago I bought ten or twelve pairs (mostly for people in my office) and kept several pairs for myself. They were about $50 per pair back then. I have one left that I am using and will continue to use until it breaks. My headset is used heavily all day long, every business day. When it breaks I will use the new pair (maybe).

Unfortunately, the new pair and another new Logitech pair I just bought (with a host of its own serious design flaws) were the closest in design to the tried and true Plantronics pair I am currently using. The state of the art has moved backwards. I would pay $50 today to buy a new pair of my old headset simply because everything about the design is correct - and it would probably only need to cost half that much.
Reviews.title: Disappointed

Reviews.text: Being a frequent user of Skype, and having heard and read that headsets are better than the microphone that comes with webcams, and computer speakers due to occasional feedback issues, I was guided by the many positive reviews on Amazon and purchased this one. The loudness controls on the cable are a real plus, and the on/off button is also convenient. A software download is necessary in order for the latter to function. The problem with this headset is the sound quality--on both ends. There is a distinct echo effect (could be classified as a distortion) that I have found to be both annoying and disappointing. The people with whom I have spoken have the same experience listening. Not enough to return it, but bad enough to give the headset a perhaps generous three stars. The earphones are a bit snug, but not objectionable. I only use the headset with Skype and cannot speak to other uses, but I would not purchase this headset again.
Reviews.title: Borderline okay

Reviews.text: I bought my first pair of Plantronics 478 a year ago. I'm very picky and do a lot of research before deciding on a purchase, specially with PC headsets as I don't use speakers. Deciding on a good pair of headsets is not easy as most have either bad sound quality, they break easily or they don't last long. When it comes to PC headsets I always bought Plantronics. MY previous USB DSP headsets broke after 7 years of constant use (can't complain!), so I decided to test the 478 as a replacement. They have very good sound quality for the price, they seem to be sturdy (1 year so far and they perform like new), and they have excellent design for travel and voice IP. They are so good that I bought a 2nd pair this year for my notebook and as a spare just in case. I recommend this headset, you won't regret at all! Thanks Plantronics!!
Reviews.title: Excellent headsets by Plantronics

Reviews.text: I received the headphones a day early and was also pleasantly surprised to find it in perfect condition. The packaging was good and sufficient padding was provided. The headphones have good sound (I'm not an audiophile and the music I was listening sounded good to me) and are comfortable for the first hour or so, but it starts getting kind of uncomfortable when you reach the 2 hour mark. Additionally due to the flexible frame (it is compact and can be folded), It keeps slipping off my head which is really annoying. But I would say that it's a good balance of functionality and sound, and if it's a few dollars cheaper, it would be a no-brainer in the foldable headphones category.
Reviews.title: Could be more comfortable, but has good sound

Reviews.text:
I have owned multiple Plantronics DSP-500 USB headsets, which are now discontinued. They indeed canceled the noise during recording, and they recorded quite clearly (good frequency response). This newer Audio 478 headset, in contrast, does not live up to that reputation whatsoever. It records absolutely no better than standard-issue 3.5mm analog microphones. There is plenty of noise -- no more, but no less, than standard analog PC mics -- and the sensitivity is also substandard when considering how close the microphone is to the mouth. Admittedly, I did not experience any problems with breathing sounds, but the puffball on some mics takes care of that pretty well. I thought that being like 8 years newer, this microphone would be able to provide --at least-- the quality of the older DSP-500, especially since even budget digital cameras and other sound equipment is so much better these days than it used to be, but I guess Plantronics decided to throw away the idea of caring about sound quality. I would not recommend this headset for anything other than basic gaming and chatting, and maybe cheap voice recognition. This headset is not suitable for even semi-professional applications.

PS: Yes, the noise can be cancelled using third-party software, and Skype could do that for all I know, but the unit alone does not -- despite it clearly sounding like it does in its description. For those curious, I used Windows 8, 64-bit, with the built-in drivers, for this product test.
Reviews.title: Not what I call noise-canceling

Reviews.text:
The wires going into each side of the headset from day one continually wound around each other under my neck, creating a nice strangulation effect. No amount of dangling to reverse the effect keeps them apart.

The control with hangup and mute buttons is conveniently placed front and center, just where the edge of your desk is likely to be. I have muted or hung up calls many times by inadvertently leaning into my desk while talking.

I wish I had returned them.
Reviews.title: Okay sound. Really annoying design.

Reviews.text:
Easy set-up. Works great with Skype on my Windows 7 PC.

Though the headset is just as advertised, if I were to buy again I would try a model with cups that fit around the ears instead of this model, which has flat foam pads that rest on the ears. The foam gets warm when worn for long periods. Perhaps this is inevitable with any style except in-ear, which has its own comfort issues.

Another opportunity to improve the design would be to place the mute button in a more convenient area. I frequently mute/unmute when on conference calls and I have to hold and look at the control to know what mode I'm in (a light goes on/off to show the mode).

Audio quality is reported by those on the other end of the line to be excellent, but the microphone also picks up outside noises like birds just outside an open window. I have not used other headsets so I don't know if this is common or not.

Overall, a good product for the price.

The microphone seems to manage to mitigate backgound noise, at least the minor variety in an office setting.

I have listened to recordings of my online gaming communications posted on the gaming site, and the voice quality was clearer than I expected.

The headphones are very good for spoken conversations, and fine for audio (but don't expect to be blown away by the depth or range of sound). I bought these because I was using my wife's headset for weekly web narration and hers were very uncomfortable.
These do feel pretty flimsy, I would have been happier without the folding option, but I don't foresee them breaking if treated well.

The biggest issue is the sound quality of recordings. Compared to my wife's Logitec 350, these are awful. But I should mention that I didn't realize the Logitecs were $130 (My wife has good taste). So in light of that, I can't complain too much about this set vs others in this price range.

I have other Plantronics headsets and they have always been acceptable, but never great.
This headset is more comfortable that the $130 Logitecs but still not great. Maybe my head is an odd shape or something, but these are too tight and the top band is long and flat unlike my head. Very odd design. If you have a smaller, flat-topped head these should fit great.

Reviews.text:
I bought these in December 2013. I'm very hard on headphones/headsets, and these don't even show a sign of wear and tear. Usually by now, I would have lost, torn or destroyed at least one of the earpiece cushions.

I bought them especially for Skype calls, and I thought they were a problem at first. There's only one person I Skype with, so I finally discovered that the horrible echo I was hearing had nothing to do with me, rather it had to do with the person on the other end with their volume on their laptop too high.

A note about comfort...As someone who has a relatively small head, wears very thick glasses, has long hair, and wears earrings, it's been difficult for me to find a headset that didn't hurt my ears. When I got these, I expected the same thing...ear pain. But I figured I'd just deal with it like I always have. But that's not what happened. When I first put them on, I had to adjust the band to fit me, but I got it to a comfortable spot. My expectation was as they got older, they would settle into discomfort. But as I write this email, and wear the headphones often 12+ hours per day, they're still just as comfortable as I took them out of the box.

I never expected these to have amazing sound output or input, but again, I was surprised. If you're a music quality connoisseur, then you'll want a pair of headphones or a headset that cost you around $100. But with a price tag right about $30, they're great for everyday use, especially for Skype calling.

Lastly, I would like to say that the price is very reasonable for what you get.
Reviews.title: Had these for awhile now

Reviews.text: I got this so I could use Skype quickly and easily, and it does 3/4 of that job, which is my only issue. It sets up easily, and when an incoming call is received, you just click the integrated cord-control, and you're talking. Hit the same button again, and you hang up. The volume controls are also a nice touch, since you don't have to be in front of the laptop to change or even mute a call. The one thing it lacks is the ability to initiate a Skype call. I'd like to see the same button you answer with, when not in a call, to pop up Skype on screen and let me select a contact to call, and initiate the call. Overall, very nice, and the carry bag was a nice little add-on. Good sound on phones and mic.

Reviews.text: The sound is good and the microphone is very good. I like that the controls are easy to access and I didn't have to do a single thing to set it up but plug it into my laptop. I was able to take it out of the package and immediately start working on my spanish assignment that required me to record my voice. From opening the package to finishing the assignment, it was completely done within 10 minutes and it took me a bit more than 10 minutes to do the assignment. My only complaint is that they are really uncomfortable after about 40 minutes to an hour. I was too lazy to take the headphones off when I completed my first assignment and just kept working on other written assignments for another hour. My ears really hurt right now. So if you're planning on wearing them for long periods of time, then look for something else. For the price though, I wasn't expecting ultra soft, fluffy, comfortable earphones. The quality is much better than I expected for what I paid. Certainly wouldn't use these headphones for a long gaming session or even a long skype call no matter how clear my voice sounds.

Reviews.text:
I purchased 10 of these for the office to use with Skype calls. I chose these headphones as they were decently priced and had good reviews.

Our team uses these daily for many calls and the audio quality is a massive improvement over using webcam microphones.

PROs:

- Significantly clearer audio than a webcam mic.
- Open-ear design allows you to stay involved in your surroundings without having to constantly remove and replace the headset.
- In-line digital volume control and mute buttons are very convenient.
- USB connection makes them easy to use on Mac and PC without dedicated headphone and mic inputs, I regularly swap these between my Windows desktop and my Mac laptop.

CONs:

- I don't think that the foam ear pads will last a long time.
- Audio quality isn't amazing, you'll not really want to be using these to listen to music.
Reviews.title: Decent audio, cheap, nothing amazing.

Similar to a phone, it cuts down on the really low end bass but keeps the chunk of mids and some highs.

Padding could be added to make it comfortable over longer periods of time, but it does fold up well and compact for travel and does hold up to travel abuse.

Overall, I'd recommend it.

Reviews.text:
I've been looking for a headset that works well on my small head, and works on both Windows and Mac. Since I have a Mac Pro (not Macbook, but the desktop variety) the mic input line is non-standard (well, an Apple standard). Having a USB connection is perfect for this combination of needs! I've used it twice now with great results. I can hear and be heard. It is a little tight so I wouldn't want to wear it all day, but I was quite comfortable during a 2 hour long Skype meeting.

The buttons on the cord are handy as well. There is a mute button, volume up/down buttons, and a skype answering button. I mostly use the mute button so far. Although it claimed to need software installed for the buttons to work on Windows, it worked for me without doing that (Windows 7).

It comes with a simple bag to keep it in, and folds up for travel. My husband has bulkier headphones that fold up to about the same size though, so I wouldn't buy this specifically for portability as it's not impressive in that feature. But, it's handier than having to carry it around in headphone shape, and they are quite light.
Reviews.title: Great for video conferencing on Mac and Windows, wouldn't want to wear all day

Reviews.text: So much nicer than my previous Microsoft and Logitech headsets. I use Skype for 2 hours daily using this thing, and it couldn't be more crystal clear. Plus everyone on the other end has commented on how much better I sound.

I bought this headset to use with Google Voice and it has excellent quality.

The only downside is that the Phone answer icon on the headset doesn't work with Google Hangout so you have to click on the answer button to accept calls. Volume up and down works fine as it should, with calls or videos.

The person on the other end said they couldn't tell the difference if I was on a land line or calling over VoIP. Hands free talking is a great benefit as well and the headset fit my large head no problem.

Finally, this was plug and play on Windows 8.1, I just connected it to a free USB port and Windows found the driver and set it up.

Reviews.text:
I use this headset for gaming and teamspeak on my computer. I dont have to shout to be heard and it picks my quiet voice up perfectly. The headphones are pretty comfy and are portable. They come with their own bag! I did not know that. It has a volume control on the headset with a mute button and a phone call button for Skype users. I find I have a tenancy to bump the volume button and end up muting my volume by accident. I also hit the mute button too and end up muting the mic. I love how the headset folds for easy storage and I love the long cord. I am very happy with this headset.

UPDATE: The headset I received started glitching. The sound cut out intermittently in both ears simultaneously. They are shipping me a new one. I will keep you posted on how the replacement functions. I do have to say, Amazon was VERY fast dealing with the issue. They scheduled UPS pick-up of the defective headset (hey, it happens) and have already shipped the replacement with the whole process taking 5 minutes. I am VERY pleased right now at the ease and speed of all this.

I really like the mute and volume controls on the cable. The USB makes this PnP, no set-up required with Win7. I also like the earpads are foam and do not surround the ear because I want to be able to hear some periphreal sounds. It does not have a foam windscreen for the mic, but no one I have spoken with has made comments to indicate I would need it. I use this at home, but could see where the ability to fold and carry would be a benefit for someone that wanted to use their own personal headset at work versus one supplied by the employer.

Reviews.text: Great product. Speech recognition has very low error rate (although a lot depends on how well you train your computer). I fly rarely and am not an audiophile, so the sound quality is very acceptable. The set is highly adjustable. It's easy to flip around for mic to be on either side, and to rotate up out of use when just listening. And here's a bonus for the visually challenged - it is left/right agnostic, so you don't have to hunt for the tiny and fiendishly hidden L or R to determine which way to put it on. It folds up very compactly (fits easily into laptop case). I like the separate wire to each eaprpiece design. The USB dongle is compact, unlike the oversized ones that are common in many models. The cord is generous in length, so it works well with desktops that might be several feet away. I deduct half a star on one account only - the top of the headband is square rather than round, so if you prefer a close fit, the weight is transferred to your skull by one one hard plastic, dime-sized spot. A little foam strip applied here makes a huge difference, easy to add on. I like it so well that I have one for office and one at home.
Reviews.title: Great performer, 4 and a half stars (Senior Citizen reviewer)

Reviews.text: This is a great little headset, especially for the price. It's lightweight and snug, easy to forget you're even wearing it. Music sounds GREAT coming through this headset. I also use it for speech recognition when I write. Very happy with this headset!

Reviews.text:
I just got this today, and I must say I quite like it. It was easy to install the software needed to use the Skype buttons, and it was also easy to download the software that needed to be installed upon plugging the device into my USB port. It was definitely easy to get out of the package.

The sound isn't all /that/ fantastic, but for a $25 headset, it's pretty decent. The buttons work fine, too, and people seem to be able to hear me alright.

My only complaint is that the earphones do get uncomfortable on your ears (not unbearably so; it's more just a warm sensation on your ears that eventually gets uncomfortable).

Other than that, this is a pretty good product.

Three of these headsets were purchased for faculty to use during their presentations for a webinar. Two out of the three used the headset during the webinar. Although I can't speak for the faculty on how they felt about the headset, I was able to understand them crisply and clearly. The volume was also excellent. I can compare the headsets as well to the one faculty who did not use his headset. He used his computer speakers and mic and his voice sounded muffled. Not crisp and clear as the others using the headset.

I will be placing an order for 6 more sets for the remaining 2013 webinars on the schedule. Hope this helps.

Reviews.text:
I bought these because the price is very low for a company like Plantronics. I use it for Skype calls. So far everyone has commented how much better I sound now. So the microphone seems very high quality.
The sound I hear is very clear, distinct, and it's so much easier to understand the other party. Most my calls are overseas to non-English speaking countries. It's actually easier to understand them now.

So these are unbeatable for VoIP, gamers, and business people looking for an extremely high quality headset to make calls with.

The other surprise is how nice they sound listening to music. These are no Fostex TH-900's but with a little equalization, they actually sound pretty good.

They fold up nicely for travel, and have nice inline controls. Note, when muted, the mute button lights up red. A small detail but makes a big difference to know you're muted.

Reviews.text:
Review for: Plantronics Audio 478 Stereo USB Headset (Audio 478)

Headset quality test based on:
- Using skype (voice over internet protocol) VOIP.
- Music mp3.
- Youtube video.

Pros:
1) Sound clarity for receiving end of my voice: indistinguishable from a landline connection.
2) Sound clarity for sending end (my end): indistinguishable from a landline connection.
3) Comfortable, rotatable ear pieces to conform to geometry of side of the head and adjustable height; well
 designed and functional.
4) Works well on PC and Mac.
5) For PC, the four button dial module on the cord is fully functional.
6) Microphone boom rotates (left or right side) out of the way for using the headset to listen to music.
7) Microphone boom can bend to modify proximity of microphone to mouth.
8) Headphones fold up compactly and can be stowed in carry pouch provided.

Cons:
1) Mac (iMac G5) software is not provided for OS 10.4.11. On four button dial module on cord of headset
 plugged into the iMac G5:
 call answer/end button: non functional
 volume increase: functional
 volume decrease: functional
 mute: functional
 (Note: If need to end the call then just use the computer into which this headset is plugged)
Reviews.title: Plantronics Audio 478 Stereo USB Headset works well for Skype

Reviews.text: I love the fact you can mute the phone conversation from the cord. But be careful, because I have also accidentally hung up on people when I just meant to mute the conversation.

Reviews.text: Purchased for use with Skype and to avoid using the microphone/audio jacks on my laptop. I had to download software from the Plantronics website to complete the installation (instructions included) but once completed it works incredibly well. All indications are that the sound quality is excellent (no complaints so far). The cord has convenient controls to answer calls, mute the microphone and raise or lower listening volume. Highly recommend.

Reviews.text: They are a little uncomfortable for extended use because they fold. They don't really deliver high quality sound suitable for serious music listeners. They do a very good job of delivering voice and conversational sound without a lot of background noise. The microphone seems to be pretty good and is convenient if you find yourself needing it. I use these at work to listen to dialog files then stash them in the bottom of my backpack for weeks at a time before pulling them out again. They still look and act like new even though I don't treat them like they are delicate. I just store them in the provided stash bag. They aren't the smallest earphones in the world but they do cover my ears comfortably enough and seem to block a decent amount of ambient sound.
